title: Apprenticeship by Geographical Region and University Presence.
Apprenticeship by Geographical Region and University Presence.
text:
Dataset

english_education <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2024/2024-01-23/english_education.csv')

#The dataset I plan on using is from the UK office of national statistics and has data about eductation attianment based for multiple towns and cites. We can see the dimensions of the the data below as well as the name of the columns by running the below code.

english_education <- english_education |> select(activity_at_age_19_appprenticeships, rgn11nm, university_flag)
write.csv(english_education, file = "data/edudata.csv", row.names = FALSE)

A brief description of your dataset including its provenance, dimensions, etc. as well as the reason why you chose this dataset.
The data set contains columns related to towns, town codes, town names, population, regional information, coastal classification, job density, income, university presence, and education attainment statistics. The dataset contains 1104 rows and 31 columns.
Make sure to load the data and use inline code for some of this information.

title: Apprenticeship by Geographical Region and University Presence.
text:
Questions
The two questions you want to answer.
For my first question will be to look at the the relationship between university presence and region on the number of 19-year-old in apprenticeships.
For my second question I want to see if there is a relationship between higher income and job density leads to higher education scores. This would suggest that economic factors play a significant role in educational attainment. (Just noticed that only one question is required for individual teams, this question will be a backup question)
Analysis plan

For question one - I need to normalize the 19-year-old in Apprenticeships to the population as we would expect that towns with a higher population would have larger numbers of 19-year old. To normalize this I will sum all the activity at 19-years columns and then find the percentage of those in apprenticeships. This will be our Y-axis. Our x-axis will be if their is a university present. Then I will have the regions set colors.


#The columns that look at ativity of 19 year olds
english_education |> 
  select(starts_with("activity")) |>
  names()

[1] "activity_at_age_19_appprenticeships"

#Regions that we will be looking at;
unique(english_education$rgn11nm)

 [1] "East Midlands"            "South West"              
 [3] "East of England"          "Yorkshire and The Humber"
 [5] "North West"               "West Midlands"           
 [7] "South East"               "North East"              
 [9] "London"                   NA                        

#data for determine if there is a univierty present to look at if a university is present
unique(english_education$university_flag)

[1] "No university" "University"    NA             



For question two - I will created a 3D scatter plot with the following variables. X-axis will be income, Y-axis will be job Density and the Z-axis will be Education score. I will also add color to the education score to add a heat map effect to clearing distinguish where we are seeing high educational scores.

title: Apprenticeship by Geographical Region and University Presence.
text: This project utilizes a dataset from the TidyTuesdayR website (January 23, 2024) focusing on educational attainment in English towns, provided by the UK Office for National Statistics. It investigates why young people in smaller towns often outperform those in larger towns academically, incorporating metrics such as population, regional classifications, coastal status, job density, income levels, university presence, and educational outcomes. The analysis examines the relationship between university presence and regional differences in the number of 19-year-olds entering apprenticeships, hypothesizing that the absence of a university might lead to higher apprenticeship rates. Initial visualizations using geom_point and geom_boxplot plots reveal that towns without universities generally have higher apprenticeship rates, with significant regional variations. Key findings indicate the highest apprenticeship rates in non-university towns in the North West, while the North East shows the greatest median apprenticeship rates.

It investigates why young people in smaller towns often outperform those in larger towns academically, incorporating metrics such as population, regional classifications, coastal status, job density, income levels, university presence, and educational outcomes. The analysis examines the relationship between university presence and regional differences in the number of 19-year-olds entering apprenticeships, hypothesizing that the absence of a university might lead to higher apprenticeship rates. Initial visualizations using geom_point and geom_boxplot plots reveal that towns without universities generally have higher apprenticeship rates, with significant regional variations. Key findings indicate the highest apprenticeship rates in non-university towns in the North West, while the North East shows the greatest median apprenticeship rates.

title: Apprenticeship by Geographical Region and University Presence.
text:
Introduction
This project utilizes the data set from the week of January 23, 2024 on the TidyTuesdayR website. This data setÂ  focuses on the educational attainment of young people in English towns. Provided by the UK Office for National Statistics, this data set explores why children and young people in smaller towns often perform better academically than those in larger towns. The data includes a variety of metrics such as population, regional classifications, coastal status, job density, income levels, university presence, and detailed educational outcomes at various stages, from Key Stage 2 through age 22.
I chose to use this data set because, upon reviewing it, I immediately envisioned the variety of compelling visuals that could be created from the rich and detailed information it contains. The diverse metrics, ranging from educational outcomes to economic factors, present numerous opportunities for insightful data visualizations.
For my analysis with this data set, I will examine the relationship between university presence and regional differences on the number of 19-year-olds in apprenticeships. This question interests me because it combines educational infrastructure with geographic diversity, potentially revealing how the presence of universities and the specific characteristics of different regions influence the career paths young people choose. My initial thought would be that the absent of a university would push more 19-year-olds into apprenticeships due to the pursing university endeavors is an available option.

title: Apprenticeship by Geographical Region and University Presence.
text:
Approach
I begin by wanting to create a simple graph to view the data. Therefore, I start with a simple geom_point plot.









The geom_point plot gives me an idea of the data, however, there is to much going on in this visualization. I also suspect that there is a lot of hidden data due to overlap. The next approach will give us an idea of the distribution of the data. This is achieved by creating a box pot visualization of the data using geom_boxplot.









This give a better representation of the data set. We can see that the median values of 19 year olds in apprenticeships is greater in towns without universities present compared to those town with universities. There is still a lot of data clustered together with this visualization so I use facet_grid to create columns by region and row by the university flag. This visualization makes easier to compare the data between all the interested variables.

title: Apprenticeship by Geographical Region and University Presence.
text:
Discussion
Interesting discussion points that I found from visulizing the data set. The towns with the highest percentage of 19 year olds in apprenticeships is town without university in the North West region. However these town are outliers, the region with the greatest median percentage of 19 year olds in apprenticeships is the North East. Another interesting observation that I noticed was that the spread of the distributions is greater when looking at towns without university and is more consolidated in towns with universities present.

title: Apprenticeship by Geographical Region and University Presence.
Apprenticeship by Geographical Region and University Presence.
Apprenticeship by Geographical Region and University Presence.
Apprenticeship by Geographical Region and University Presence.
text:
Conclusion

North East and North West regions have higher median of 19-year olds in apprenticeships
The distribution spread of 19-year olds in apprenticeship is greater in towns with no university and more consolidated in towns with universities
The North West contains the towns with the highest precentage of 19-years olds in apprenticeships but they are outliners.
The North East region has the highest median number of 19-year olds in apprenticeships
